Why Sony Bank choosing Billions actually matters
‚Ä¢ Privacy by default

Sony Bank can verify users without ever seeing or storing personal data. No raw data, no honeypots, no leaks.

‚Ä¢ Zero-knowledge proofs in production

This isn‚Äôt theory or testnet hype. Real customers, real transactions, running today at institutional scale.

‚Ä¢ KYC + privacy can coexist

Billions proves compliance (KYC/AML) doesn‚Äôt require surveillance. Privacy and regulation are no longer opposites.

‚Ä¢ Lower risk for institutions

No personal data storage means reduced legal liability, fewer breach risks, and simpler internal security models.

‚Ä¢ Faster onboarding

Users don‚Äôt need to resubmit sensitive documents repeatedly. Verification becomes smoother and less intrusive.

‚Ä¢ Lower operational costs

Less data handling, fewer compliance headaches, and reduced infrastructure overhead.

‚Ä¢ Institution-ready infrastructure

This is why banks like Sony Bank ‚Äî alongside other global institutions ‚Äî are adopting Billions.

‚Ä¢ A signal for the future

The next generation of finance won‚Äôt be built on collecting more data, but on proving truth without revealing it.

Sony Bank is showing what the future of KYC looks like.

Through a pilot with SettleMint and @billions_ntwk ,they‚Äôre able to verify customers using zero knowledge KYC without ever touching or storing sensitive personal data. The bank only receives proof that a user is valid, not the data itself.

The benefits are clear: 
far lower risk of data breaches, cheaper and lighter compliance, faster onboarding, and real user privacy. This isn‚Äôt theory the technology has already been tested at the scale of major banks.

With Sony also preparing a USD stablecoin for 2026, zkKYC feels like the missing puzzle piece a real bridge between traditional banking, blockchain, and digital worlds like gaming and entertainment.
Practical technology, not hype.

Billions recently announced the partnership with Sony Bank and SettleMint.

Let 's dig into this three party collaboration.

Like every financial institution, Sony Bank involves a trade off between compliance and usability. Traditional KYC means no privacy, centralized user data with full access everywhere. That is not something that Sony Bank could compromise under regulations.

Building with SettleMint 's chain infrastructure platform, Sony Bank integrated @billions_ntwk on zero knowledge KYC, with which users prove their eligibility not exposing extra personal data. 

This ZK and on-chain verification approach is not just a theory. It is already grounded on real users and real transactions by Sony Bank. As it proved, major financial institution can adopt web3 without surveillance, usability is improved while compliance is not traded. such a peaceful scene and Billions make it real.

One thing Sony Bank just proved with @billions_ntwk is important:

You don‚Äôt need to see user data to verify users.

Real customers. Real transactions.
Zero-knowledge KYC at institutional scale.

Privacy and compliance aren‚Äôt enemies outdated systems are

Token launches keep getting hijacked by sybil farms and bot swarms
Sentient wanted $SENT to land with real contributors without building a surveillance style verification system

1/ The partnership behind it

Sentient worked with Billions and Clique to design a privacy first human first claim flow

2/ Who is who in this setup

Billions is the Proof of Uniqueness layer
You prove you are a real unique human using zero knowledge proofs so the system learns unique human yes but never learns your identity

3/ Clique is the eligibility gate

It runs checks like region constraints and wallet risk screening inside TEEs trusted execution environments which are secure hardware zones that can process sensitive checks and still keep inputs protected

4/ How the claim flow felt for users

Open the Sentient portal
Complete a quick liveness selfie once
A ZK proof gets created
No photo storage
No central identity database
If you are unique you pass and you can claim

5/ What Sentient got out of it

Fewer duplicate claims and less bot leakage
Cleaner distribution that rewards real builders
A repeatable template other teams can copy when they want fairness at scale without intrusive KYC

BILLIONS NETWORK x SONY BANK: THE BRIDGE IS BUILT üè¶

The @billions_ntwk has just confirmed a massive validation milestone with Sony Bank in Japan and the implications are huge

Here is the breakdown of what just happened:
1Ô∏è‚É£ The Partner: Sony Bank (A giant in Japanese Finance)
2Ô∏è‚É£ The Tech: Billions proprietary Zero-Knowledge (ZK) identity stack
3Ô∏è‚É£ The Win: They successfully demonstrated "Proof of Uniqueness" verifying users are real humans without exposing their private data

Why does this matterü§î
We talk about "Mass Adoption" all the time but this is what it actually looks like
Banks are strictly regulated. They can't just "use crypto." They need compliant, secure, and privacy-preserving tools.
Billions just proved they are the missing link between traditional banking (TradFi) and the new digital economy (Web3)
With Japan preparing to launch major stablecoins and crypto regulations Billions is positioning itself as the identity layer for it all

Don‚Äôt sleep on this. The institutions are here and they are choosing Billions üöÄ

1. What Sony Bank did
Sony Bank ran a pilot program
where Billions‚Äô zero-knowledge KYC was used
for stablecoin and Web3 services.

2. Traditional KYC vs the new approach
In traditional KYC
customer data is copied
stored in databases
spread across multiple systems
which increases the risk of data leaks.

Sony Bank avoided this
and chose a privacy-first approach
while still fully meeting all regulations.

3. How zero-knowledge KYC worked
With Billions
customers only proved that
ü™Ñ their age was valid
ü™Ñ they were residents of a specific country,

But
no name
no address
no documents
were revealed.

4. Where the data lived
All credentials stayed
inside user-controlled wallets
using W3C standard DIDs.

Meaning
the customer remained the data owner
not the bank.

5. How verification happened
Using smart contracts
everything was verified
ü™Ñ instantly
ü™Ñ privately
ü™Ñ in a compliant way.

6. This wasn‚Äôt just theory
On Sony Bank Connect
real users
real transactions
were processed
using zero-knowledge proofs.

7. The results
‚úÖ Faster customer onboarding
‚úÖ Lower data storage risk
‚úÖ Reduced operational costs
‚úÖ Better user experience

8. The bigger picture
Sony Bank now stands alongside institutions
like HSBC and Deutsche Bank
that are adopting @billions_ntwk.

9. Final takeaway
In modern finance
privacy and compliance
can scale together

Sony Bank didn‚Äôt just understand this
they proved it in practice.
